snippet: A city long overshadowed by nearby New York and Washington has learned to take pride in the creativity born of its relative affordability.
abstract: Democratic Party picks Philadelphia as site of its 2016 national convention, move that may prove to be an economic boon to city with highest percentage of people living below poverty level than any other large American city; Philadelphia's story is one of contrasts--while millennials are flocking there and beefing up town's technology sector, crime rate is still high and school system remains troubled.

byline.original: By JON HURDLE and JENNIFER STEINHAUER
byline.contributor: Jon Hurdle reported from Philadelphia, and Jennifer Steinhauer from Washington. Kitty Bennett contributed research.

lead_paragraph: A city long overshadowed by nearby New York and Washington has learned to take pride in the creativity born of its relative affordability.

headline.main: Democrats’ Convention Choice for 2016 Reflects a Philadelphia Resurgence
headline.print_headline: Democrats’ Convention Choice for 2016 Reflects a Philadelphia Resurgence
